Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Chelating Ligands for the Aggregation, Dissolution and Bioavailability of Soluble Nanomaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Soluble nanoparticles (NPs) of metallic and mineral oxide constituents are a class of nanomaterials now widely produced for commercial purposes. Despite their significance, the transformations controlling dissolution rates are not well understood. Dissolution rates of these NPs are likely to be affected by interlinked reactions including aggregation, deposition, and metal complexation by ligands. Synthetic surface coatings, often used to stabilize NPs and reduce aggregation, will also affect dissolution. Each of these processes will influence NP persistence and exposure in the environment and may do so in synergistic or antagonistic ways that determine subsequent reactivity, bioavailability, and toxicity. In this project the PIs seek to understand how two critical processes affecting NP transport and fate aggregation and dissolution combine to regulate the persistence and exposure of NPs through impacts on metal speciation and availability to target organisms. The work will investigate at a fundamental level the individual and collective effects of dissolution, aggregation, metal ion complexation and uptake resulting from NP exposure. In particular, the interactions between the surfactant coatings and natural organic ligands will be examined.
The outcome of this work will be disseminated through scientific publications and conferences. Broader outreach to the public will occur through existing programs including a nationwide nanoscience education initiative with science museums and a local science and engineering education program for elementary school girls. The proposed work will directly support the education of graduate, undergraduate, and high school student researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project resulted in the following key outcomes:

1) We developed and validated a method to quantify rates of ZnO and CuO dissolution in environmentally-relevant aqueous media. This method utilizes anodic stripping voltammetry to quantify dissolved metal concentration in a mixture with nanoparticles. The method allows for quantification in time scales of minutes to hours. The method was validated independently with ultracentrifugation for separation of dissolved species from nanoparticles followed by analysis of the metal by ICP-MS. This method was published in Jiang and Hsu-Kim, Envion. Sci. Proc. Impacts, 2014.

 

2) We demonstrated that dissolved natural organic matter (NOM) can accelerate the rate of nano-ZnO and nano-CuO dissolution. Previous work demonstrated that NOM can increase the solubility of the nanoparticles at equilibrium with the solution phase but much less was known about the kinetics of dissolution. Moreover, the rate of NOM-promoted dissolution of ZnO NPs increased with the equilibrium dissolved Zn concentrations in NP-NOM mixtures. This result could be applicable to previously published studies reporting trends in ZnO equilibrium solubility, which tends to be easier to quantify than dissolution rates

 

3) We demonstrated that the extent of NOM-promoted dissolution correlated to certain characteristics of the NOM, namely the aromatic carbon content. This work also demonstrated that specific UV absorbances can serve as a facile and reliable indicator of NOM-promoted dissolution of ZnO NPs and possibly other metal-based nanomaterials.

 

4) We demonstrated that there is no correlation between Ag uptake into fish embryos (bioavailability) and toxicity. We observed no significant differences in Ag uptake from Cit-AgNPs into F. grandis embryos across a salinity gradient, whereas there were substantial differences in toxicity across this same gradient. Furthermore, there wasn’t even a trend suggesting some kind of relationship between uptake and toxicity. This disconnect between dose and hazard poses a challenge for accurate risk assessment.

 

5) We showed that cysteine, a model silver ligand, alters Ag-mediated toxicity from both dissolved Ag and some Ag NPs. We also showed that for Cit-AgNPs dosed across a salinity gradient, cysteine can alter both Ag uptake and toxicity, but uptake is altered at only a single salinity with no difference in toxicity, and toxicity is altered at two salinities, but neither shows reduced uptake. This further complicates the process of predicting potential toxicity associated with environmental nanoparticle exposures.

 

6) The project contributed to the education and training of 4 graduate students, 1 undergraduate student, and 2 postdoctoral associates.

 

7) Major concepts of this project were disseminated to the public through the NanoDays event at the N.C. Museum of Life & Science (Durham, NC). NanoDays attracted thousands of visitors from the Raleigh-Durham metropolitan area. We developed an activity that informs the public about promising applications of nanotechnology and the potential concerns for environmental health and safety. Our specific activity was called “NanoToss” and was a demonstration to teach children (and their parents) the role of surfactants for the ‘stickiness’ of nanoparticles.
